s.text: Game shows do have many of the same advantages as true reality-based programming--relatively low production cost, endless supply of material--and some others in addition, including the ability to keep Chuck Woolery off the dole.

We don't, it's true, know how any given episode of Millionaire is going to turn out, and even though one might say the same about a forthcoming episode of ER , the fact that in theory no one knows how the Millionaire episode is going to turn out may make it more real.
It's their success that prompted a recent headline in Variety proclaiming "Nets Reap Ratings From Reality Shows."
It's their success that prompted a recent headline in Variety proclaiming "Nets Reap Ratings From Reality Shows."
What's odd about this is that game shows--even if they're not fixed like they were in the '50s--are real only in a very tenuous sense.
Why Who Wants To Be a Millionaire Is a Hit
